TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the Court by PERSON of ORG , solicitors practising in GPE , GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant ’s father ( ORG ) and mother were not married when he was born and did not subsequently marry . ORG did not have any other children . ORG died intestate on DATE , leaving an estate with a net value of GPE CARDINAL .

On DATE the applicant ’s solicitor wrote to the solicitor acting for ORG ’s parents pointing out that the applicant was ORG ’s son and noting that in DATE had paid a lump sum to the applicant ’s mother in response to her maintenance requests . The applicant ’s solicitor requested a declaration recognising ORG as the applicant ’s father . It was accepted that under NORP law the applicant could not , as a child born outside wedlock , inherit on his father ’s death intestate ( ORG v. S ( DATE ORG CARDINAL ) ) . However , he wished to complain to this ORG about that unequal treatment and , in default of receiving the requested declaration , the applicant would issue proceedings to obtain a declaration of paternity from the courts . In DATE the applicant ’s solicitor received a negative response to his request .
Letters of administration were granted to the deceased ’s brother on CARDINAL DATE .

On DATE the applicant ’s solicitor wrote to the Chief State Solicitor requesting a declaration recognising that the applicant was ORG ’s son so that the applicant could take a case to this ORG about the differing treatment on intestacy of children , in default of which the applicant would issue proceedings . On DATE the Chief State Solicitor responded that according to section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) the Attorney General , for whom the Chief State Solicitor acted , could only be introduced to the proceedings by way of court order without which the Attorney General had no role in the matter .

On DATE the applicant issued proceedings in ORG against ORG ’s mother and against the Attorney General . He claimed that his inability to inherit on intestacy was discriminatory and that he was desirous of bringing proceedings before ORG . He sought a declaration , pursuant to section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW pursuant to the equitable jurisdiction of the ORG , to the effect that ORG was his father . In DATE an order was made striking out the applicant ’s claim against the Attorney General and identifying the Administrator of ORG ’s estate as the sole appropriate defendant .

By letter dated DATE to the Chief State Solicitor , the applicant put the Attorney General on notice that the terms of any declaration of parentage would be relied on by him in an application before this ORG .
On DATE the applicant issued amended proceedings in accordance with the court order of DATE .

The applicant was unsuccessful before ORG and appealed to ORG . In DATE ORG ordered that blood samples be taken from the applicant and from ORG ’s mother and brother . The matter was finally heard on DATE and , by judgment delivered on DATE , ORG declared , pursuant to section CARDINAL of GPE and to its equitable jurisdiction , that ORG was the father of the applicant . It ordered the Administrator of the estate of ORG to pay to the applicant the costs of the proceedings .

At common law , an “ illegitimate ” child had no succession rights to either of his parents . The Legitimacy Act DATE gave an “ illegitimate ” child and his mother limited reciprocal succession rights on the other ’s intestacy . LAW DATE did not change the position .

Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act provided that the estate of a deceased is to be distributed in specified portions between any surviving spouse or “ issue ” . By judgment of DATE ( ORG v. S ( DATE ORG CARDINAL ) ) , ORG found that the word “ issue ” did not include children who were not the issue of a lawful marriage , the latter having therefore no right to inherit on the intestacy of a natural parent . It also found that sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act did not infringe the principle of equality guaranteed by LAW ) of LAW .

The CARDINAL Act was enacted on DATE and came into force on DATE . The purpose of this legislation was to equalise the rights of children whether born within or outside marriage and Part V of the DATE Act makes the relevant amendment to the law relating to , inter alia , succession on intestacy . Upon the death intestate of a parent , a non - marital child would have the same intestacy rights as a child born to married parents . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act makes it clear that the changes to the rights of inheritance on intestacy of children brought about by the DATE Act “ shall not affect any rights under the intestacy of a person dying before the commencement of Part V ” of LAW .
